comments.body: breadcrumb to where this value ends up
newline
Add a paragraph before this, something like "A message to show when the dropdown is disabled."
fyi @HansMuller
what i find weird about this approach is that it's asymmetrical. Why do we clamp at zero but not at some equivalent large offset?
Remove extra blank line.
Done.
What do you bet someone reports a typo for "Free"? :-)
I was hoping someone would: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_Four

I have been trying get my commas straight per this madness: https://www.grammarly.com/blog/comma/

I believe this is an example of "Comma Between Correlative Conjunctions". The comma isn't needed.
English grammar is so broken. At least I learned something today!
Blah blah blah "Comma Between Correlative Conjunctions" :-)
This might be a little clearer as: `... widget.style.fontSize ?? Theme.of(context)...`
What if onChanged is null? Are we missing a test?
Since onChanged is handled like this `onChanged: onChanged==null? null : field.didChange(value)`. I guess `onChanged` won't be null here(in didChange).
As far as I understand, this makes sense because `field.didChange` is only ever called when `onChanged` is not `null`... although reading the logic at first glance was somewhat confusing.
Sounds good. To prove that we're expecting onChanged != null here, please assert as much.
Done

Sorry, I hadn't noticed this before: why are we creating all of these fields? These parameters are all just getting passed along to the super call; there doesn't seem to be any need to make them fields of DropDownButtonFormField.
Sorry @HansMuller , couldn't get you. If we donot create those fields, how are we going to pass parameteres from DropdownButtonFormField to DropdownButton and FormField. 😕

I think what he means here is that you can just do: 
```
    Widget disabledHint,
    int elevation = 8,
    // rest of properties
    double iconSize = 24.0,
    bool isDense = false,
    bool isExpanded = false,
```
and remove all of the corresponding properties on `DropdownButtonFormField` itself. If `DropdownButtonFormField` is not directly using any of these properties and they're just being passed down to `DropdownButton`, then there's no need to define them here.
If that's possible, that helps us avoid duplicating the properties, as well as having to template out the docs as you already have.
That's right: all of the new values are being passed along via the `super()` call, there's no need to squirrel them away in this class.
@HansMuller @shihaohong Is this ok ?

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +949,953 @@    FormFieldSetter<T> onSaved,
    FormFieldValidator<T> validator,
    bool autovalidate = false,
    Widget disabledHint,
    int elevation = 8,

comments.body:
Yes, this is my big question and probably where I struggled the most: By reading the spec, it seemed like many of these alt-texts were actually not necessary to the content and I was using it more as an "Accessibility Label" for people using screenreaders so they knew the image being displayed was basically what was described in the paragraph above.

Following [this portion of the spec](https://html.spec.whatwg.org/multipage/images.html#a-graphical-representation-of-some-of-the-surrounding-text), it seemed the best thing to do in these cases is simply remove the alt-text, so that's what I've done -- often providing a more thorough explanation in the paragraph above.

It felt a bit strange, but that was my best attempt at complying with the spec. Would certainly love input on these changes, @Hixie!

I am inclined to think it is okay since it seems to be the prevailing pattern in the codebase.  
If not, we can always return and update. 🙂
